https://www.earth.com/news/humans-were-using-fire-to-cook-food-780000-years-ago/
>The question of when early humans began using fire to cook food has been the subject of heated scientific debate for over a century. Until recently, the earliest evidence of cooking dates to approximately 170,000 years ago. However, a close analysis of the remains of a carp-like fish found at the Gesher Benot Ya’aqov (GBY) archaeological site in Israel provides proof that the fish were cooked roughly 780,000 years ago, thus predating the available data by over 600,000 years ago.

>By studying the structure of pharyngeal teeth belonging to the fish fossils, the scientists were able to prove that the fish caught at the ancient Hula Lake – adjacent to the archeological site – were exposed to temperatures suitable for cooking and were not simply burned by a spontaneous fire. The fact that fish cooking is evident over such a long period of settlement at the site indicates a continuous tradition of cooking food, and adds evidence to the high cognitive capacities of the Acheulian hunter-gatherers who were active in that region.

>According to the scientists, the transition from eating raw food to eating cooked food had major implications for human development and behavior. Since eating cooked food reduces the bodily energy required to break down and digest food, it allows other physical systems to develop, and leads to changes in the human jaw and skull. Such changes freed humans from the daily, intensive work of searching for and digesting raw food, providing them sufficient free time to develop new behavioral and social systems. Thus, eating fish can be considered a major milestone in human cognitive evolution, providing a central catalyst for the development of the modern human brain.
Probably not your normal wheelhouse /ck/ but thought you might be interested in this. Incidentally, I wonder what woolly mammoth tasted like?

last_replies.com: You can make your own scoby. Use coffee filters, and the seal around the filter has to be tight.

last_replies.com: Look up a recipe, I’m not typing it all out. But: you have to use only white sugar and preferably lipton’s black tea. Everything should be as clean and sterile as possible. It has to be room temp before you put the Scoby or kombucha in. It needs air and I think it likes the dark.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I managed to grow a scooby successfully from a flavored kombucha bottle, only did 2 batches before moving out for uni though. Gasification and good flavoring are the actual difficult parts. If you ever need help there is a very good discord, called Fermented Foods or something like that, that has some very knowledgeable and helpful people that will share tips and help you make sure you're not growing any dangerous mold instead of kombucha.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
As others have said, homemade is almost guaranteed to be better than storebought if you put in a little effort. I was blown away to find the very first attempt at making it myself was the best booch I'd ever had. You'll save money, learn some practical fermentation skills, and produce a finer beverage; the only reason not to make your own is if you lack the time.
It's a hardy culture and as long as you clean things after use you should have no worries about contamination. Other than expense, a big part of what drove me to make my own was that every decent brand started cutting sugar in favor of "healthy" sweeteners, only for the taste to suffer and the culture to be impaired. Plain white cane sugar is their favorite sweet, and plain black tea (use a budget-friendly loose black instead of bags for a noticeable improvement) is their favorite tea; there's little reason to give them anything else for the first ferment.

>>18614674
>Bonus if you secondary ferment with grape juice.
Grape kombucha kicks ass. Like with wine it seems to just have the perfect sugar levels for this sort of thing.

I got my SCOBY (and later my kefir grains) from "The Kefir Lady" on her site, highly recommend her if you're in the US.

Remember to add a TINY pinch of xanthan or guar gum to your homemade mayonnaise to ensure it is ultra-gloopy like commercial mayonnaise is. Thin mayonnaise simply won't do!

I use the lowest speed on the immersion blender. Pulsing for a while until it starts to visibly thicken up on the bottom then I lift it up a little, gradually and incorporate the rest of the oil.
I add 1 clove microplaned raw garlic, 3 egg yolks, 1.5 lemons juiced, 2 tbsp maple syrup (I like a sweet n sour effect to mimix commercial mayo), .5 tsp salt and I used about 1.33 cups of sneed oil. I don't measure any of this except the oil, the rest is just estimates.
